snippet:
Egypt, the most populous country in the Arab world, claims one of the world’s oldest cultures, descending from an ancient civilization that emerged in the 10th millennium BCE.

Widespread Middle East unrest in 2011...
lead_paragraph:
Egypt, the most populous country in the Arab world, claims one of the world’s oldest cultures, descending from an ancient civilization that emerged in the 10th millennium BCE.

Widespread Middle East unrest in 2011 loosed grievances against the 30-year autocratic rule of President Hosni Mubarak, who was ousted following a dramatic period of protest that became a watershed moment in the Arab Spring. This upheaval paved the way for the country’s first free parliamentary elections, in which the Muslim Brotherhood leader Mohamed Morsi was elected president. Subsequent protests against Morsi’s authoritarianism led to a 2013 military coup d’etat and the election of former general Abdel Fattah el-Sisi as president in 2014.

Learn more about Egypt. Scroll below to view our archive of articles and chronology of latest news.

headline.main: Egypt

lead_paragraph: As Israel and the Palestinians prepared for talks to extend a truce, a senior Hamas leader said the group would keep its political and military wings separate, allowing the latter to prepare for another potential war.
abstract: Hamas, preparing for peace talks with Israel, announces that it will keep its military wing separate from any new coalition government, and allow it to prepare for future conflicts; move could undermine negotiations, which aim to disarm Hamas and form new unity government, and could lead to new clashes with Israel.

snippet: Three years after the United States left Iraq, its return to the region is getting a less than enthusiastic welcome, with allies finding ways to avoid specific commitments to an expanded effort against Sunni extremists.
lead_paragraph: Three years after the United States left Iraq, its return to the region is getting a less than enthusiastic welcome, with allies finding ways to avoid specific commitments to an expanded effort against Sunni extremists.
abstract: Return of United States to Middle East three years after withdrawing from Iraq is getting a less than enthusiastic welcome among Arab nations; leading allies like Egypt, Jordan and Turkey are all finding ways to avoid specific commitments to Pres Obama's expanded effort against Islamic State in Iraq and Syria; thirteen years of chaos have deepened political and sectarian divisions and increased mistrust of US on all sides.

headline.main: Arabs Give Tepid Support to U.S. Fight Against ISIS
